titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the UH Business Manager (McElhinney) Records
titlestmt.author: Andrea Bean Hough, June 1997; Bobby Marlin, 2003

titlepage.titleproper: Guide to the UH Business Manager (McElhinney) Records 1945/1973

did.head: Overview of the Collection

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

did.abstract: The Business Manager Records of C. F. McElhinney are the records McElhinney generated during his tenure at the University of Houston (1945-1973).

bioghist.head: Biographical Information:
bioghist.p: Charles Flemming McElhinney (commonly known as C. F. McElhinney or “Mr. Mac”) was born on Sept. 19, 1907 in Truro, Nova Scotia. He received a bachelor’s degree from Acadia University in 1926 at the age of eighteen and taught in public schools in Canada before continuing his graduate studies. He received a master of arts degree from Columbia University in 1928.

Mr. McElhinney taught in the public school systems in Chester Basin and Halifax, Nova Scotia before moving to the United States. He was an assistant professor at the State Teachers College in Troy, Alabama from 1930-1931 and at the Mississippi State College for Women from 1931-1934. He moved to Houston in 1934, taking the position of assistant director of curriculum and research for the Houston Independent Schools District from 1934-1939. Mr. McElhinney then became the director of research from 1939-1945, when he became the business manager for the University of Houston, which until 1945 had been operated by the Houston Independent School District. During this time he also served as a staff assistant to Mr. E. E. Oberholtzer, the president of the University.

From 1945 until his retirement in 1973, Mr. McElhinney served as the business manager of the University. During this time, he was given the position of vice-president and business manager from 1950-1962, and was senior vice president for finance and treasurer from 1962-1973. He also served as interim president of the University from 1953-1954.

During Mr. McElhinney’s years at the University, he also served as a faculty member in the department of education, and as a sponsor of several student activities and programs. Additionally he was the coach of the first athletic team fielded by the University (ice hockey) in 1934 while the University was still known as the Houston Junior College.
When Mr. McElhinney retired in 1973 (at the end of the fiscal year), the Board of Regents renamed the Graduate Studies building in honor of McElhinney’s decades of service to the University.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use:
userestrict.p: Special Collections owns the physical items in our collections, but copyright normally belongs to the creator of the materials or their heirs. The researcher has full responsibility for determining copyright status, locating copyright holders, and abiding by current copyright laws when publishing or displaying copies of Special Collections material in print or electronic form. For more information, consult the appropriate librarian.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: UH Business Manager (McElhinney) Records, Courtesy of Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Business Manager Records of C. F. McElhinney are the records McElhinney generated during his tenure at the University of Houston (1945-1973). The collection has been arranged into six series: Board of Regents, Staff Conference Meetings, Legislative Activities, Building Files, President’s Office, and the Houston College for Negroes. The materials in the collection date from 1945-1974, with the bulk of the materials dating from the 1960s and 1970s. Included in the collection are university-related correspondence, minutes, agendas, reports, financial reports, bids, and contracts. There are no photographs or personal papers in the collection.
Key correspondents in the collection include C. F. McElhinney, Philip Hoffman, Patrick J. Nicholson, E. E. Oberholtzer, W. W. Kemmerer, and Clanton W. Williams.

The materials follow the organization in which McElhinney left them, with some minor rearrangement within folders to follow chronological order. All folder titles use the headings provided by McElhinney.

Materials in the collection document the administrative activities of the University, including Camp Wheeler, construction on the Houston College for Negroes campus (now Texas Southern University), the legislative activities of the University during its campaign for state support in the 1960s, the development of KUHT Channel 8 and KUHF, the campus radio station.

Oversized materials, including maps of campus from the 1960s, blueprints and related architectural materials on the UH Central Power Plant, and a campus map of the utility distribution system have been removed from the collection for preservation purposes. Please ask an Archives staff member for assistance regarding oversize materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
This is the largest series, 10.5 boxes or 488 folders, with the bulk of the records dating from the 1950s through 1973. The materials are arranged in chronological order with some exceptions and include agendas, minutes, memoranda, reports, budgets and financial reports. Also included in this series are the records of several sub-committees of the Board of Regents/Board of Governors. These include the committees on which McElhinney served: the Finance Committee, the Executive Committee, the Building Committee, the Planning Committee, and the Investment Committee. During 1957 some re-organization was undertaken, which created a Board of Governors to serve in an advisory capacity to the Board of Regents. This changed again in 1963, when the University of Houston gained state funding and the Board of Governors was eliminated. Generally the files are organized by month, with agendas and any attached materials followed by the minutes for that meeting.
Of particular interest are materials attached to the minutes and agendas, which include reports or memos from many of the faculty and administrators on campus. These reports address the initiation of new programs on campus as well as several major issues: construction on campus, desegregation, the campaign for state support in the early 1960s, Camp Wheeler, KUHT, and KUHF. These materials have been left with the agendas with which they were attached and therefore are found throughout the series. Materials on KUHT and KUHF, in particular, are scattered throughout this series, although there is a folder from the Ad-Hoc Television Committee in 1959 and a folder specifically on KUHT from 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series, consisting of 180 folders of material, documents the meetings held by the President of the University with his key administrators. Included in this series are agendas, minutes, correspondence, memoranda, and reports. Major issues, such as construction, finances, KUHT, KUHF, the campaign for state support, student unrest in the 1960s and 1970s, and desegregation are addressed throughout this series. Folders are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains [eighty-three folders] arranged chronologically and retaining the folder titles used by McElhinney. Included are reports, minutes, correspondence, memoranda, newspaper clippings, speeches, position papers, state publications, and related materials. This series documents the efforts of the University to achieve state support and status as a state university during the early 1960s and includes the reports sent to the University administration by Patrick J. Nicholson during the 1961 legislative session. Also included are the initial budget requests to the state by the University. One of the primary correspondents in this series is State Senator Robert W. Baker of Houston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series, consisting of ninety folders of material, deals with the planning, funding, and construction of the A. D. Bruce Religion Center and the University Center. It is divided into two sub-series, Religious Center and University Center. The bulk of the material dates from 1965 to 1966 and includes subject files, bids, financial records, correspondence, and promotional literature from various companies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series, which consists of thirty-four folders, is divided into three sub-sub-series: Subject Files, Architect, and Organ.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Subject Files are arranged alphabetically by folder title and include planning and fund-raising information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Architect sub-sub-series relates to architect Frank C. Dill’s work and the Tellepsen Construction Company. Folders are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Organ sub-sub-series relates to the various companies that wanted to receive the contract for the Religious Center organ.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series, which consists of fifty-five folders, is divided into two sub-sub-series, Bids/Worksheets and Subject Files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-sub-series includes the bids for various aspects of the University Center and worksheets relating to the various bids.

Bids, Carpet, Rug-Fashion Carpet and Interiors

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-sub-series is arranged chronologically and includes the minutes and reports of various committees, which addressed the need for a student center on campus in the late 1950s and early 1960s.

did.unittitle: Staff Study on Housing and Student Life
George Pierce and Abel B. Pierce- Architects

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of eighty-nine folders of material and includes correspondence, memoranda, reports, brochures, and other materials generated by or related to the Office of the President. Subjects covered in this series include art on campus, the Clear Lake campus, President Hoffman’s inauguration, and the president’s house. Also included are files with material from General A. D. Bruce, Philip G. Hoffman, and Clanton W. Williams. The materials are divided into the following sub-series: Art, General A.D. Bruce, Clear Lake Campus, Philip G. Hoffman, Inauguration, Clanton W. Williams, and Subject Files. Each sub-series is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of thirty folders of material, dating from 1945 to 1948 and includes receipts, financial records, correspondence, and memoranda. The bulk of the material dates from 1945 to 1947. Included are records from fund-raising efforts for construction of buildings on the campus, as well as financial records for the Houston College for Negroes.
